raw: By Tom Daly and Min Zhang BEIJING , March 27 ( Reuters ) - Aluminium stocks monitored by the Shanghai Futures Exchange ( ShFE ) have fallen for the first time in three months , data showed on Friday , although experts say this does not necessarily mean China ’s coronavirus - hit demand is catching up with supply .
replaced: By Tom Daly and Min Zhang BEIJING , Dec. 27 ( Reuters ) - Aluminium stocks monitored by ShFE have this for the first time in three months , data showed on Friday , although experts say this does not necessarily mean China ’s coronavirus - hit demand is catching up with supply .

raw: Inventories of aluminium in ShFE warehouses across nine Chinese cities and regions slipped by 5,922 tonnes , or 1.1 % from the previous week to 528,072 tonnes , having previously risen non - stop since Dec. 27 .
replaced: Inventories of aluminium in ShFE warehouses across nine Chinese cities and regions slipped by 5,922 tonnes , or 1.1 % from the previous week to 528,072 tonnes , having previously risen non - stop since Dec. 27 .

raw: But Wang Hongfei , manager of the aluminium department at Antaike , noted ShFE data only covered stocks for futures delivery and not spot inventory for immediate purchase , and said the Chinese research house ’s own numbers were higher .
replaced: But Wang noted ShFE data only covered stocks for futures delivery and not spot inventory for immediate purchase , and said the Chinese research house ’s own numbers were higher .

raw: “ Actually , spot inventories have n’t fallen at all .

raw: They are still rising , ” Wang said , adding there was a lot of “ hidden inventory ” on the market .

raw: Wen Xianjun , vice chairman of the China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association , also said aluminium stocks were still rising .

raw: While most processing plants were back at work now , their “ orders are not too good ” , he added .

raw: Exacerbating the situation is the spread of the coronavirus virus across the globe .

raw: China is the world ’s top aluminium exporter but its shipments are set to drop as overseas consumption falters , while demand for steel- and copper - intensive goods like home appliances is also likely to suffer .

raw: ShFE copper inventories fell for a second week , by 3.5 % to 364,040 tonnes .

raw: Orders over the past week were “ ordinary ” , said a manager of a copper tube maker .

raw: He did not rule out a rebound in consumption ahead , however , noting the peak summer season for air conditioners was approaching .

raw: Steel products held by traders in major Chinese cities also fell again , by 4.2 % to 24.29 million tonnes as of Thursday , according to Mysteel .
